awd_titl_txt: Theoretical Foundations of Advanced III-Nitrides Power Switching Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
The research addresses the basic understanding and optimization of various types of III-Nitride power switches such as SuperJunction structures with immediate environmental impact. This work has important applications in smart power grids, transportation systems, and electric drives for small and large vehicles. The PI plans to integrate his research in a power electronics curriculum that will address novel power devices with new functionalities. The research will provide a very strong educational platform to train graduate students in a frontier research topic, with active collaborative industrial participation. The outreach activities to high-school and undergraduate students include the Boston University High School Honors Research Internship and UROP programs.


The PI proposes to conduct a systematic approach for designing and optimizing III-Nitride based power switching devices by addressing fundamental theoretical aspects related to material properties and device structures. The characteristics of vertical devices made with such materials and operating at high-voltage and high-current will be addressed, allowing at the same time higher frequency of operation compared with traditionally used devices and thus significant system size reduction.  The PI proposes to address the challenges faced by the need for switching voltages in excess of 5KV and hundreds of amperes at one hundred kilohertz or faster by addressing the fundamental theoretical aspects related to the III-Nitride material properties and device structures and developing transformative vertical device structures such as GaN-MOS and vertical enhancement mode HFETs. The results obtained from the studies will be validated using experimental data obtained through collaboration with laboratories specializing in this area. The research is well conceived and would deepen fundamental understanding of the physics of III-Nitride MOS devices and impact of defects and dislocations, as well as channel transport.

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of the program encompass both code development, simulation of advanced device structures and theoretical defect studies.

We have developed a 3D Monte Carlo simulation code that includes all the main features of III-Nitride based devices. The code includes numerical models to evaluate the carrier lifetime in different III-Nitrides alloys, a series of algorithms to track particle in the unstructured mesh and correct of the spurious self-forces, and optimized algorithms to reduce the uncertainty of the device current.

We have applied the simulation code to perform full band particle simulation to a number of power diodes that have been manufactures by collaborators. Specifically we have investigated simulated power GaN-MOS and PIN diodes. Result validation has been performed using experimental data from literature and additional information provided by collaborators. As a result of this activity we have shown that GaN-MOS device structures can be effective as normally-off power switches.

We have investigated the properties of Ga2O3 to evaluate the potential for power device applications. Specifically we have studied the p-type doping and defects migration. We have established that Ga2O3 is unlikely to exhibit p-type behavior.

In collaboration with Sandia National Laboratory the PI's group has worked to understand the properties of AlGaN and potentially transition some of the ideas generated within the current project toward the goals that SNL is trying to achieve. We have disseminated the results of the program to a number of selected organizations that are currently developing power devices based on III-Nitride semiconductors. Some of these organizations are the same that have committed to support the research program, for example the Army Research Laboratory (ARL) and the Naval Research Laboratory (NRL).

The program has supported four PhD students, two of which have graduated during the period of performance, one undergraduate student, one high-school student and one post-doc.

Modified by: Enrico Bellotti
